channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Chapman Pincher, Fleet St. Scoop Specialist, Dies at 100
item.description: A journalist whose career was spent unearthing exclusive stories from the world of double agents and secret weapons.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Indian Border Guard Released After Brief Detention
item.description: Pakistani officials on Friday released an Indian border guard who was arrested after he accidentally crossed their de facto border in the disputed Himalayan territory of Kashmir, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing: Lebanon: Influential Exile Returns
item.description: Former Prime Minister Saad Hariri, considered Lebanon’s most influential Sunni Muslim politician, returned unexpectedly to Lebanon on Friday after three years of self-imposed exile.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: Militants Kill 15 Soldiers
item.description: Al Qaeda militants killed 15 soldiers in southern Yemen after seizing them from a public bus on Friday, military officials and witnesses said, in what appeared to be retaliation for an army offensive.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China Looks to High-Speed Rail to Expand Reach
item.description: For China, the strategic importance of a proposed line can barely be overstated: It would provide an alternate to the longer and increasingly contentious trip through the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Fear of ‘Another Benghazi’ Drove White House to Airstrikes in Iraq
item.description: Interviews with multiple officials in the Obama administration paint a portrait of a president forced by the unexpectedly rapid deterioration of security in Iraq to abandon his longstanding reluctance to use military force.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN, MARK MAZZETTI and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Pesh merga fighters on Friday near a Kurdish checkpoint west of Erbil, a city where there were concerns that the advance of ISIS would pose a risk to Americans.

item.title: While Offering Support, Obama Warns That U.S. Won’t Be ‘Iraqi Air Force’
item.description: The president, addressing critics in both parties, asserted that the United States has a “strategic interest in pushing back” ISIS.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama said on Friday that Iraq’s leaders must form an inclusive government in order to pull the country together.

item.title: Differences Between Israel and U.N. Over Gaza Episodes Go Back Years
item.description: Israeli attacks on United Nations facilities are repeating a pattern that an agency board of inquiry reported in 2009. Israel says it is addressing the issues.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Turkey’s Premier Tries to Keep Power, as President
item.description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is expected to win Sunday’s presidential vote and transform an office that has been largely ceremonial.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and TIM ARANGO

item.title: New Fighting a Bid for Leverage as a Gaza Cease-Fire Expires
item.description: Hamas fired a barrage of rockets while Israel struck back and said it would not negotiate under fire and the U.N. secretary general expressed disappointment.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: A girl inside a United Nations school hosting displaced Palestinians in Gaza City, where plastic bottles stood empty, awaiting the return of the water supply.

item.title: Motorbikers in North Korea Are Told to Park to Save Fuel
item.description: Motorbike use by ordinary citizens has been cut to rush hours to ensure fuel for the government and the military personnel, two websites that monitor North Korea said, adding that a decline in Chinese oil imports was probably responsible.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. Jets and Drones Attack Militants in Iraq, Hoping to Stop Advance
item.description: American warplanes launched airstrikes against Sunni militants in northern Iraq on Friday, destroying rebel positions around Erbil, the Kurdish capital.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN, TIM ARANGO and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Airstrikes targeted militants outside Erbil on Friday.

item.title: Half a Ton of This, Half a Ton of That: Russia Is Calm Over Food Import Bans
item.description: Retaliatory sanctions against Western products have led to a “buy Russian” campaign and some signs that there were ways around the problem.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A dairy farm that began operation on Friday in Petrovskoye, in the Leningrad region. A “Buy Russian” campaign for food is underway.

item.title: U.N. Agency Calls Ebola Outbreak an International Health Emergency
item.description: The United Nations health agency said the outbreak warranted extraordinary measures but stopped short of imposing a travel ban.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Liberian nurses prepared to carry the body of an Ebola victim on Wednesday.

item.title: At War Blog: A Letter to the President, and a Well-Timed Response
item.description: In June, a Marine Corps veteran who was a judge advocate during the Vietnam War wrote to President Obama, expressing concern that militants’ advances in northern Iraq might prompt the United States to send troops back there. The response he received seemed prescient.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Opinion: The Youngest Are Hungriest
item.description: Why do eldest sons in India overshadow their siblings? Because they’re literally taller.
item.dc:creator: By SEEMA JAYACHANDRAN and ROHINI PANDE

item.title: Diplomatic Memo: Iraq Strikes Seen as Giving Putin Pretext in Ukraine
item.description: If Russia sends forces into Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin can point to the American intervention in Iraq as justification for protecting a population under siege.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: The Saturday Profile: 90-Year-Old Sex Columnist Shatters Taboos in India
item.description: Mahinder Watsa, a gynecologist in Mumbai, tackles matters of sexual anxiety in his Ask the Sexpert column in a daily Indian newspaper, and tens of thousands of people have sought his help.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mahinder Watsa, 90, is the “Ask the Sexpert” columnist for The Mumbai Mirror. In India, discussing sex openly is still taboo.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Lawyers, in Closing Argument, Say Murder Charge Is Too Strong
item.description: Lawyers finished their formal submissions and the case against the double-amputee sprinter was handed over to Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa for a verdict.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: The trial of Oscar Pistorius was drawing to a close on the 41st day.

item.title: W.H.O. Declares Ebola in West Africa a Health Emergency
item.description: The United Nations health agency said the outbreak warranted extraordinary measures but stopped short of imposing a travel ban.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Liberian nurses prepared to carry the body of an Ebola victim on Friday.

item.title: Blast in Ukraine’s Capital Stirs Fears of New Conflict
item.description: The explosion, which injured at least two people, came as protest barricades and tents still stand in the central square months after demonstrations that toppled the government.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: A Boy at Play in Gaza, a Renewal of Warfare, a Family in Mourning
item.description: Hundreds gathered to mourn Ibrahim Dawawsa, 10, the first casualty in the latest chapter of the battle between Hamas and Israel in the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and FARES AKRAM
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sabah Dawawsa, center, mourning her 10-year-old son, Ibrahim, who was killed in an Israeli strike on Friday.

item.title: Afghan Rivals Back a Deal, Once More, for President
item.description: The two candidates reaffirmed their commitment to accept the results of an internationally monitored recount of votes regardless of who prevails.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with Ashraf Ghani, to his right, who was ahead in preliminary results from the runoff, and Abdullah Abdullah, second from right, his opponent.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Li Hu, AIDS Activist, Dies in Beijing
item.description: The death on Wednesday of Li Hu, a campaigner for the rights of people with H.I.V./AIDS, has drawn together a group of people in China who struggle with widespread discrimination.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Li Hu, who drew national attention in China for his advocacy for people with H.I.V./AIDS, died on Wednesday in Beijing. His sign reads: "H.I.V.-infected people need equal rights to a healthy existence."

item.title: Opinion: Britain’s Drinking Problem
item.description: The experiment to discourage overconsumption would have a greater chance of success if it were bolder.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLES NEVIN
